entry.title: Combined summary - smart contracts -- possible use case? yes or no?
entry.summary: Bitcoin's regulatory environment is uncertain in many geographic regions, which raises questions about the need to pay capital gains and sales taxes. Neil Fincham requested that the focus should be on technical issues related to Bitcoin development. Gavin Andresen agreed with him but there were concerns about the role of taxation and donations in Bitcoin development due to the dissatisfaction with how these funds are typically spent. The idea of voluntary donations to the government for Bitcoin service providers was proposed, but it was pointed out that most people are not satisfied with how their donations are spent. The discussion centered around the possible solutions to ensure that donations align with the donor's preferences and are spent in the right place. Smart contracts could be one of the solutions to this problem.In a discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list, Mark suggested that providing external audits of customer accounts without revealing private data could be useful beyond taxation. Adam Back responded by noting that there are examples in taxation where anonymity is accepted, such as with certain types of investments in Swiss banks. He suggests that such methods could also be possible for Bitcoin and recommends discussing this topic on the Bitcoin Talk forum instead.The regulatory environment in many geographic regions for Bitcoin is uncertain, causing confusion on issues such as capital gains and sales tax. However, in most regions, Bitcoin is considered "just another currency" and taxed the same way as any other currency. A suggestion has been made to voluntarily pre-empt legislation by giving donations to the government (aka taxation) for Bitcoin service providers. Although this might seem like a good idea, the problem with voluntary donations is that most people are not satisfied with how their money is spent. To fix these issues, some suggest donating directly to the cause you want to support, such as the fire department.Overall, the discussion highlighted the complexity and controversy surrounding taxation and government spending. The hope is that smart contracts can help achieve a better democracy that benefits everyone: citizens, government, and innovation alike. The Bitcoin-dev mailing list had several discussions on taxation and donations, including the idea of donating directly to the cause one wishes to support, such as the fire department.
